segments.text: Wednesday, August 2nd.
Testing, testing, testing.
Wednesday, August 2nd.
Testing.
Testing, testing, two.
Testing, two.
Testing, two.
Testing.
Today is August the 2nd.
And I have the great honor of chatting with Roland Gonzalez.
Ralph.
I'm sorry, Ralph.
Son is Ralph.
Ralph Gonzalez, class of 53.
As we begin, sir, tell this machine about your family background, your parents, where did they grow up, and where did you live, and so forth, growing up.
Well, my mother came over from Mexico when she was two years old.
And they came over.
There was no restrictions on immigration at the southern and northern borders of the United States.
However, there were on the east coast and the west coast.
And so, people would go across a bridge in Laredo
free and back and forth until 1910.
So my mother came over with her four brothers and her father and mother, and they came on a horse and wagon.
They got to San Antonio.
I don't know how long the trip took, but there was no place to stay.
So they stayed at one of the missions.
because of the marauding Indians and safety.
And then from then on they looked around and found a place to live.
So my grandfather was, as you probably know, the field of education in Mexico was almost nil.
And the people were just lettering.
Not that they were dumb, they just didn't have the facilities to go to school.
So my grandfather, that's my mother's father, still had his horse and wagon.
And he, I don't know how he got it, but he was real light-complexed.
He looked more like Anglo than Hispanic, blue eyes, brown hair.
And he'd take his horse and wagon down to the Katy Depot up on South Flores.
And in those days, people used to travel for a couple of weeks or so, and they used trunks and big suitcases.
And it was a custom of the railroad people that they would hire
these wagons, horse drawn vehicles, to deliver the trunks and the suitcases to the addresses.
And that's how my grandfather made a living.
And then my father, he came from Mexico also.
He was born over there.
And the four brothers of my mother

were skilled in bicycle mechanics and in other words they could do more with their hands and because they didn't have the education and in those days they had the bicycle races from san antonio to new raffles or seguin you know and uh so uh my father was one of those that wanted to ride the bicycles and he met the boys and then he met my mother and so
So my father was, he could read music.
And he was a drummer.
And he gave lessons too.
And I learned how to play drums.
And he worked in a grocery store in San Antonio.
But on weekends he had his band and they'd play at dances.
What kind of music did they play?
or dance music.
And so they had a good following and someone decided that hey, if you fellas dress up like Charles you can go on a tour.
And we'll get an agent to go ahead and book you at those days there were night clubs.
Sure enough they got the uniforms and they went on a trip and they were gone two years, believe it or not.
Finally the end of the tour came up and it was closed and the musicians began to come home, except my father.
He decided to stay up there.
Up where?
I think it was Chicago.
And he stayed over there and then later we found out that he asked for a divorce.
My mother didn't know which way to go.
They had no advisors or anything.
But divorce was granted, and so that was the end of him.
How many brothers and sisters do you have?
I have one brother and two sisters.
And what part of San Antonio did you grow up in?
Westside.
Westside.
San Antonio was divided.
All the black people moved to the east side.
All the Hispanics went to the west side.
So whenever there was any repairs to streets and so forth, we were the last ones to get it.
And then the well-to-do were on the north side.
And then there was mostly Anglos that lived in the south side.

Okay, so I recall that the Ursuline Academy had a tower, and it had four sides, and there was a clock that you could see from the, and there was a clock on the east and west and south side, but none on the north.
Well, why was that?
Well, you see, there was nothing on the north side except just jungle and mesquite.
Jackrabbits, deer, and so forth.
So who wanted to see the time over there?
And so people ask that question to this day.
Okay, so when I was eight years old, I was the oldest, my grandmother decided that
I had to go out and make some dickles and dimes.
So the only thing I could do was go and sell newspapers.
And I got to a period where I knew just about the name of every street.
And my playmates were, one was Jewish, three were Anglos, and two were black.
So I picked up English just like that, see.
So when they put me in school, I just overheard some of the teachers doing recess.
They said, I wonder how Ralph got to speak so good English.
He said, all the rest of the other Hispanics, they're having trouble, you know, communicating.
And they couldn't understand why I could be, okay.
I went to the grades, and I went to UNF Austin Elementary School.
And I recall that there was one student there that was very nice and friendly, and his name
And it was Gonzales, just like mine, but with a Z at the end.
And he became Congressman Gonzales.
Henry B.
And then there was Albert Pena.
And Albert Pena, he became a judge in the municipal court.
And let's see, there was Edward Neary.
His dad was, he worked for the Yellow Cab Company.
and he was a starter there at the San Anthony Hotel.
And I just happened to bump into him because I was running around selling newspapers.
Mr. Neary, he was Hispanic, but he could pass for an Anglo because he was of this complexion.
And these yellow cabs were lined up on the street, so when one of the clients there at the San Anthony Hotel wanted to go somewhere, he was the starter.
And so it was a nice arrangement.
I mean, going to school and learning and this kind of thing.
And my grandmother always wanted me to be a mail carrier.
And I don't know why.
I actually figured it was a sure thing.
It was a good job.
I didn't think much of being a mail carrier.
So, I grew up and went to school and I had to sell papers in the afternoon.
I wanted to take- Which paper was that?
Which paper?
Both.
The San Antonio Union News and the San Antonio Light.
Both were the afternoon then?
Well, in those days,
They had editions.
Oh, that's right.
About every two hours, two or three hours.
We had the street edition, the noon edition, the afternoon edition, the financial edition, and the last one, final.
And a lot of people didn't want to buy the paper in the daytime.
They wanted the financial because they wanted to see what the stock market had now.
Did you stand on the street corner selling it, or did you deliver them?
Oh no, I saw them on the street.
You see, I could have gotten a route on a bicycle, the paper was only two cents, but I didn't have the money for a bicycle, and we were poor, I tell you.
So I saw my papers on the street.
And you learn to fight.
Because there's always some bully that wants to, or one that doesn't want to do nothing and to go out there and put you in a corner and take your money away.
Or to tear your papers or whatever.
So at the beginning I was afraid and I would cry.
Then I saw some other boys that wouldn't put up with it and they'd fight.
So I started hitting back, and I found out that the bullies backed off when they saw that I was fighting.
Anyway, and to this day, to this day, I notice that among the Hispanics, they're ready to fight.
Because when they're growing up, they're abused, they're kicked around, discriminated against, and all these ugly things that happen to people who live at the poverty level.
So I wanted to take part in sports.
And so I wanted to very much to play baseball.
And I wasn't good at basketball.
I wanted to play baseball and football, but I couldn't because I had to go sell papers and make some wrinkles and dyes for lunch the next day and whatever.
Now which high school did you go to?
San Antonio Vocational and Technical High School, which was later changed to Fox Tech.
So things were pretty hard there.
At that time they were just trying to come out of the Depression.
Franklin Delano Roosevelt was doing everything he could to put people to work.
So I became a high school dropout.
And I sold papers in downtown San Antonio.
And there was a Sellers Drugstore No.
2, Wagner's Drugstore, and the Robert E. Lee Hotel.
And so for two years, I was out.
And so finally, I realized that I couldn't get a job because I didn't have a, they always asked me, well, did you finish high school?
Do you have a high school degree?
No.
So I told him, look, I'm going to have to go back to school and find some kind of job after.
Well, I went back to Fox Tech.
Well, it was still San Antonio Technical School.
And I finally made it.
What year did you finish high school?
And I was 21.
So then things started to change.
And I got a job working, I started working after school at night, working for the Monument Chevrolet Company on Florence and Martin.
Joe and Harry Freeman owned that business.
And that worked.
ten, sometimes twelve bays or stalls where mechanics worked.
And my job was to clean up the stalls with grease, get the trash out, and I'd work right after school until about eleven or twelve o'clock at night.
What was your pay, do you remember?
Yes, sir.
The mechanics would pay me fifty cents a week, and the company paid me four.
And it ended up with ten dollars.
And you know ten dollars was money then, you see.
So sometimes I'd go to sleep in class because of them.
So I quit and I went to California thinking I'd get a better job over there.
It didn't pan out so I came back.
Now I hopped the freight.
And I went over there to Los Angeles, but I had to get off in, I can't think of the name right now, because the bulls were out there picking up hobos and everything.
So I had to take a streetcar or a bus to go into L.A. And when I had to come back, it was the same way.
And I had to die because the yards, the railroads,
They were full of police, you know, and they were picking up these vagrants, you know, and some of them would break in those boxcars and steal what was inside.
So I came back to San Antonio and the boss that I had there said, look, we got a boy here that took your job.
But the parts department, Frank Wyatt, he needs somebody that can talk Spanish over there in the parts department.
I had experience working on cars.
I knew parts and everything.
So Mr. Wyatt said, I'd like to have you come over here.
You have a good memory, you remember numbers, and you're bilingual.
So I started ten dollars a week.

I wore a shirt and tie then, you know, and so Mr. White, he would go visit the garages over on the west side, you know, to solicit business and also tell them, hey, I've got a place over here on Forest and Martin.
And I'm giving you a regular 25% discount, and if we don't have the parts, we'll get them for you from the other dealers, or we will order them for you.
So sure enough, I had some of those Hispanic mechanics had a limited English vocabulary, and they could express better in their own tongues.
And so they tell me,
I want this and this and this for a white model car.
And the word got around, see, because at that time I didn't make a, I didn't do any research.
In the contacts I had with the other automotive supply dealers, stores, I was the only one.
I was the only Mexican that was working in the Forest Department, see.
And pretty soon
Pretty soon, people from Mexico were coming over.
And of course, Harry Freeman used to talk to them about selling them new cars, new trucks.
And I remember one of them came in there to buy a 1940 Chevrolet four-door sedan.
And the price was $940.
So, I worked there in the parts department, and people were coming there from Mexico to buy parts to take back to Mexico.
And some of them would, they would ask for different information, and they would send correspondence.
They had other Hispanics working there, see, but they didn't know.
And that is, they couldn't translate.
So they called me, they said, well, what does this guy say here?
He says this and this and this.
Okay, well listen, can we call him on the telephone or something?
So that's what I was doing.
Then the war came.
Then the war, well not yet.
We had something like three or four automobile dealers in Mexico that were having difficulty getting parts from the factory back in the States.
It was a slow procedure, so they would come to us to order big parts.
to order Pontiac parts, this kind of thing.
So, and so I got the promotion until 19, just before the war.
I would make $25 a week.
Hey, that was good.
So every payday I'd give my mama $15 and I'd keep $10.
And my first car was a 1928 Chevrolet.
It was old, but it would take me there and bring me back.
And nobody else in my neighborhood had anything.
They had bicycles, you see.
Well, so the war broke out, and on weekends I would drive a wrecker.
And every time we had a police radio.
Every time there was a call, we'd say, car so-and-so, go to this intersection.
And that was for a major accident.
And there were other garages that had the same thing.
They would rush out there.
And whoever got there first, usually would get the car.
So that was a Sunday.
It was late, maybe about 5 o'clock.
And I heard these boys hollering, you know.
I didn't know what the heck they were hollering about, you know, because we were listening to the radio.
So one of the boys brought a paper and says, Pearl Harbor bombed.
And I didn't get the significance of it, see.
It had maybe one or two paragraphs, and it says, the radio became silent on contact.
to San Antonio, Los Angeles, and it wore.
Yeah.
So, it wasn't long.
It was, let me see, about a week, week and a half.
The draft board number two sent me a card.
Greetings.
Report to the draft board so and so for induction.
So I went to Harry Freeman and says, meet up.
I'm helping the family out, then can you maybe
talk to the draft board and give me an extension or something.
Well, Freeman called me in and says he wouldn't do it.
So then the parts manager says, look, with the knowledge you have about Chevrolet parts, or General Motors parts, he says, don't go to the draft board.
They'll put you in the infantry and they'll make you German fodder.
Cannon fodder.
He says, Hitler's boys are going to shoot you.
They told me that in a joking manner.
He says, the best thing for you to do, you go sign up now and tell them you want to go into the ordnance department.
That's where they got all the vehicles.
Well, I did that.
Now, when did you volunteer?
Do you remember when that was?
Well, January 17, 1942.
And so I wanted to get in and go into the ordnance and, hey, let me do my stuff, you know, before I know what to do.
But that never came about.
It never came about.
And I requested it in writing and everything.
And they wouldn't accept me.
At the same time, I had a cousin of mine that went in, and he wanted to be an airplane mechanic.
And he was telling me later, he says, they lined us up.
And we said, I'd count off.
And I said, I was counting.
He said, start with 50.
I said, all right.
You guys are going to the Cooks and Baker School.
And he says, I don't want to go.
I don't want to be a baker or a cook.
He says, I want to be an airplane mechanic.
Well, that's where he went.
Someplace up in Alabama.
Had a school over there.
So we got to, let me see, we turned over to Dodd Field, which was adjacent to Fort Sam Houston.
And there we got
inducted and gave us the uniform.
And my past life was too long, the uniform didn't, you know.
So I got, I think it was a couple of days off.
I went home and I had my mother, you know, alter the fine things.
So they put me on the train to go up to Paine Field, Washington.
This was in Everett, Washington.
The day it was called, the day it was changed to Everett Air Base.
And so that's where we were sent.

And instead of going to Aberdeen and train, you know, this kind of thing, and learn close art of drill and so forth, there was a first sergeant there at Peyton Field that he had some time in the Army.
And because of the restrictions and because of the inadequacy of the basic, they made a training field, a training base.
And so they got this first sergeant to teach us close order drill and learn how to break down or disarm small arms and rifles.
Because we were going to be armorers.
And so this is what happened.
So then in June, we were to ship out.
So we got our orders to be sure to check all our equipment, our clothes and everything, and get it ready.
And everybody was asking, I mean, the troops were asking the First Royal General or anybody else there.
Where are we going?
We're shipping out, but where?
They wouldn't tell us.
Then we got a notice on the bulletin board from the supply sergeant, come on over there and pick up your mosquito bars.
That did it.
I said, I know where we're going.
Oh boy, we're going to the southwest Pacific area, and sure enough.
So, and we were half scared and worried because
We heard all kind of ugly stories that the Japanese were committing atrocities and how they would torture American soldiers.
And boy, it was awful.
But anyway, we just had to do the best we can.
So we went on the USS West Point.
It was a liner, but it was a
It was converted to a troop ship, and I don't know how many were on it, but it was a whole bunch of people.
And we noticed that some of them were musicians, you know, they had accordions and everything.
But the top stoop of the ship was for officers and nurses, see.
Oh, I tell you, we wanted to talk to the girls too, you know, but off limits, can't do it.
So we got to Melbourne, Australia.
It took us fifteen days to go across, and we had one submarine scare.
We were expecting a torpedo to hit from a Japanese submarine, but it never occurred.
So we got into Melbourne, and there was no place for us to stay.
They had a place called ASCOT, A-S-C-O-T, Speedway.
And it was a racetrack, really.
It was a stadium.
And that's where we stayed.
It was cold as hell, I tell you.
See, the weather was the opposite from the States.
And they got some cannabis.
And they made some walls, windbreakers is what they were really, because the wind was coming in and it was chilly, I don't mean.
And we'd sleep with our uniform and overcoat to keep warm.
And so finally we got our orders to move up.
Now we have Australia, I guess you already know
Austria has a province or a state, and the gauge of the railroad is one width.
And when you get to the border to go into the other, the gauge changes.
I said, my God.
So we had to unload everything, trucks and everything, drive along, and get on one or the other train.
And then they had to stop.
and the engineer or somebody up in the front came out with a can of oil
